title: Harrowing 999 call murdered youth worker made as he lay dying airs in shocking BBC documentary

A murdered youth worker who was stabbed metres from his north London home managed to call the emergency services with his dying breath.

Kwabena Nelson, known as Kobi, was targeted by gang members on February February 3, 2018, in the park behind his home in Tottenham.

His murder investigation resulted in the conviction of just one person, 21-year-old Neron Quartey, but detectives believe three other suspects are still walking free.

In the hard-hitting BBC documentary The Met: Policing London, Kobi's harrowing 999 call hears him begging for help.

"I've got stabbed," the breathless young man tells the operator.

(Image: JMeyaaNelsonxo / Twitter)

"Where are you, mate?" he's asked, to which he replies: "St Mary's Close... St Mary's. I'm dead."

The operator asks him to be more specific, and Kobi answers again: "I'm dead. N17 Tottenham."

The emergency services staffer reassures him that police and paramedics are on their way to him, and a weak Kobi whispers: "Please... hello."

Kobi managed to make a final call to his brother Kojo and girlfriend Tracey, and Kojo raced to the scene in a desperate attempt to save his brother's life.

Kojo calls 999 again and is heard pleading with his dying brother to talk to him.

(Image: BBC)

(Image: BBC)

"Are you with him now?" the operator asks.

"Yes," he sobs.

"Are the attackers still nearby?"

"No he's by himself. It's serious there's a lot of blood," Kojo panics as his brother screams in pain next to him

"Kobi, Kobi... Kobi, Kobi, chat to me. Kobi. NO."

Speaking to the BBC months after his brother's devastating and senseless slaughter, Kojo revealed their final heartbreaking moments together.

(Image: Twitter)

"I remember holding Kobi in my arms and telling him 'stay with me' and he was just nodding 'yeah yeah' and then he turned around and said 'pray for me, pray for me' and that at that point I kind of froze for a split second," he recalled.

"I gave him a hug. I saw that he was in so much fear so I thought I would comfort him."

He quietly added: "The hardest thing is waking up knowing it's another day and Kobi's not here."

The brothers' mother managed to speak to her boy one last time before he succumbed to his wounds.

"That pain will never go away," she said, wiping away tears.

(Image: BBC)

"Kobi was a very good person, he tried to help everyone, family and community. I don't know what's wrong with the people who killed him. I miss him. I miss him very badly.

"This is not a game, and I don't want anybody to count Kobi's death as number. This we are talking about a whole man's life. They killed Kobi for no reason. They killed the whole family, and friends, and community."

The months after Kobi's murder saw the London borough of Haringey descend into bloody violence, with 19-year-old Kelvin Odunuyi shot dead in Wood Green in what police suspected was a revenge killing.

His killers are yet to be caught.

*The Met: Policing London continues next Thursday at 9pm on BBC1
description: Kobi Nelson's last conversation with emergency services aired as part of the BBC documentary The Met: Policing London
